It is evaluated as if there was a crediting coinbase transaction with two 0
pushes as scriptSig, and one output of 0 atoms and given scriptPubKey,
followed by a spending transaction which spends this output as only input (and
correct prevout hash), using the given scriptSig. All nLockTimes are 0, all
Test the test: we should have an empty stack after scriptSig evaluation
and multiple spaces should not change that.
Similarly whitespace around and between symbols
all bytes are significant, not only the last one
equals zero when cast to Int64
CAT must treat arguments as bytes as opposed to numeric
CAT with two empty args must result in a single empty item on the stack
CAT with empty right-hand side must return left-hand side
CAT with empty left-hand side must return right-hand side
CAT works in a conditional branch
CAT must not modify the stack if in an unexecuted branch
SUBSTR same index must produce empty byte push which is equivalent to FALSE
SUBSTR start and end index at exact length produces empty byte push
SUBSTR works in a conditional branch
SUBSTR must not modify the stack if in an unexecuted branch
SUBSTR of an empty string produces an empty byte push regardless of out of bounds indices <=4 bytes
SUBSTR start index must work with the result of math operations
SUBSTR end index must work with the result of math operations
LEFT index of zero must produce empty byte push which is equivalent to FALSE
LEFT produces entire string when end index equals string length
LEFT works in a conditional branch
LEFT must not modify the stack if in an unexecuted branch
LEFT of an empty string produces an empty byte push regardless of out of bounds index <=4 bytes
RIGHT index equal to length must produce empty byte push which is equivalent to FALSE
RIGHT produces entire string when start index is zero
RIGHT works in a conditional branch
RIGHT must not modify the stack if in an unexecuted branch
RIGHT of an empty string produces an empty byte push regardless of out of bounds index <=4 bytes
Right bit rotation related test coverage
ROTR must be able to produce a 5-byte result (0x1 >>> 1)
Left bit rotation related test coverage
ROTL must be able to produce a 5-byte result (0x1 <<< 31)
DIV must support a positive dividend and divisor
DIV must support a negative dividend with positive divisor
DIV must support a positive dividend with negative divisor
DIV must support a negative dividend and divisor
MOD must support a positive dividend and divisor
MOD must support a negative dividend with positive divisor with negative result
MOD must support a positive dividend with negative divisor with positve result
MOD must support a negative dividend and divisor with negative result
Left bit shift related test coverage
LSHIFT must be able to produce a 5-byte result (0x1 << 31)
Right bit shift related test coverage
RSHIFT of negative number must shift 1s into the high bits (0xffffffff >> 1)
RSHIFT of negative number must shift 1s into the high bits (0xffffffff >> 2)
RSHIFT of negative number must shift 1s into the high bits (0xffffffff >> 3)
RSHIFT of negative number must shift 1s into the high bits (0x80000001 >> 1)
RSHIFT of negative number must shift 1s into the high bits (0x80000001 >> 3)
RSHIFT of negative number must shit 1s into the high bits (0xaaaaaaaa >> 1)

PUSHDATA1 of 75 bytes equals direct push of it
PUSHDATA2 of 255 bytes equals PUSHDATA1 of it
Numeric minimaldata rules are only applied when a stack item is numerically evaluated; the push itself is allowed
Valid version of the 'Test every numeric-accepting opcode for correct handling of the numeric minimal encoding rule' script_invalid test
While not really correctly DER encoded, the empty signature is allowed by
STRICTENC to provide a compact way to provide a delibrately invalid signature.
CHECKMULTISIG evaluation order tests. CHECKMULTISIG evaluates signatures and
pubkeys in a specific order, and will exit early if the number of signatures
left to check is greater than the number of keys left. As STRICTENC fails the
script when it reaches an invalidly encoded signature or pubkey, we can use it
to test the exact order in which signatures and pubkeys are evaluated by
distinguishing CHECKMULTISIG returning false on the stack and the script as a
See also the corresponding inverted versions of these tests in script_invalid.json
2-of-2 CHECKMULTISIG NOT with the second pubkey invalid, and both signatures validly encoded. Valid pubkey fails, and CHECKMULTISIG exits early, prior to evaluation of second invalid pubkey.
2-of-2 CHECKMULTISIG NOT with both pubkeys valid, but second signature invalid. Valid pubkey fails, and CHECKMULTISIG exits early, prior to evaluation of second invalid signature.
Overly long signature is correctly encoded
S with invalid S length is correctly encoded
Zero-length S is correctly encoded for DERSIG
